abstract.p: Activist pastor Bill Wylie-Kellermann gives an urgent specificity to the theology of the powers, relating biblical concepts to contemporary struggles for civil rights, clean air, fair housing, safe affordable water, public education, and more, highlighting throughout the vital importance of a community of struggle connected through time and across space. The book‘s uniqueness lies in its practicality, as biblical and theological analyses arise from, and are addressed to, particular historical moments and given ecclesial and movement struggles.

abstract.p: William Stringfellow was my mentor in the practical theology of principalities. I’ve spent the three decades since his death, if not thinking like he did, at least framing my work in the outlines of this thought on the powers.
